course.subject: COMP
course.name: Computer Graphics
course.description: Display technologies; scan conversion; clipping; affine transformations; homogeneous coordinates and projection; viewing transformations; hidden surface removal; reflectance and shading models; ray tracing; spline curves and surfaces; hierarchical modeling; texture mapping; color models.
course.prerequisites: COMP 3711 OR COMP 3711H

reviews.author: haha1234
reviews.title: poor teaching with bad grading
reviews.comment_content: basic computer graphics. copied from CSE457 Spring2002 University of Washington. The materials are never updated. One of the assignment dues is the year 2003 so you can imagine how old it is. It is even older than me.
reviews.comment_teaching: poor teaching, in a casual way that nobody understands. Let me give you an example. When he talks about spline curves, he always mentioned his 95-year-old grandma who knows nothing about the computer. In fact, he  was trying to tell us how simple it is for everybody to use. But what is the point? Rather than mentioning your grandma all the time, can you just follow the lecture notes or tell us some useful materials?
reviews.comment_grading:
60% project 40% final
bad grading
rank 8 out of 72 in the final, 392 out of 400 in the project
end up getting B+?????????????????
CK told us the bonus will help upgrade the letter grade but I think doing much bonus is the only way to get into A-range.
Some people would tell you CK is transparent with the score but it means nothing. Finally, you will only be told the top 1 student get A+ which you will know even if he didn't tell you. So think carefully before enrolling in this course
reviews.comment_workload: light if you just finish the basic requirement. But it will become a boss if you try to do the bonus, which might be out of date and no one will use it in real life.

reviews.author: tintin&snowy
reviews.comment_content: Interesting content. However, most of the content is derived from University of Washington's Computer Graphics course. Also, the content can be quite theoretical as well as mathematical.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. CK is a pretty fast talker and sometimes he does not really explain clearly what the content of the lecture notes mean. I find it more useful when I read the notes that have been annotated by the professors in the University of Washington. Despite the teaching style,  CK cares a lot about his students. If you are into computer vision/graphics, you can stick to him for mentoring purposes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Projects: 50%
Homeworks: 5%
Final Exam: 45%

You should be fine as long as you do well in your projects and score as many bonuses as possible. Bonuses are useful to increase your sub grade. For the final exam, there are 80 MC and 8 long questions. Very mathematical and theoretical. Read the textbooks, review the lecture notes, and learn the projects.
reviews.comment_workload: 4 projects for a semester. They are moderately difficult to solve especially if you are aiming for many bonuses. Sometimes you need to read the textbook to know how to do the projects. After every project you will have a demo session with the professor/TA and explain how you solve each requirement. The HWs are difficult too although you don't really need to solve them perfectly to get all 5% because the TA/Prof will grade them based on your efforts/correctness etc, as long as you submit all the HWs.

reviews.author: raypeng
reviews.title: You will write a lot of code
reviews.comment_content:
Basically a coding course.
You will worry about the theory part only days before final.

what is in the 3 hour final:
80 MC (covering every corner details of the theory)
5 long questions (each with 3-5 questions; lots of math)
reviews.comment_teaching: CK cares about teaching but you will need to catch up with his speed.
reviews.comment_grading: CK gives x subgrade(s) up according to your assignment/project bonus scores. x \in {0, 1, 2, 3}
reviews.comment_workload:
minimum requirements for 4 assignments/projects are very low -- probably each only takes < 5 hours to finish
yet you can go pretty wild about getting all the bonus scores

so:
workload = want_bonus ? heaviest : lightest;

reviews.author: ogt
reviews.comment_content:
Topics: raytracing, curves, transformations, particle systems, shading, texture mapping

The content is good....as long as you are interested in computer graphics. In reality, most of the stuff taught is not useful except for doing graphics stuff, which for most of us is probably never going to happen.
Nonetheless, mostly OK. But only take this course if you are interested in the topics!
reviews.comment_teaching:
CK is a nice professor and is clearly very enthusiastic about the course and its content. He is very responsive by email (a few hours only normally). However, during class, I have a hard time staying focused sometimes as the content is quite difficult at times and the slides are not great. The slides could really do with some updating.

The TAs were also fine.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading is quite fair. The best thing about CK is that he is very transparent with the grading. For every project, you get a breakdown of your score. For every part of the grading, he releases a scoreboard that shows your rank and the scores of everyone else.

I got almost full scores for all 4 projects.
There are 3 homeworks worth 1% each, graded by effort. I didn't put in that much effort and got the marks.
The final was online, which was 95 MCQs. My opinion on this is that some questions were based on knowledge (either you know or don't), but there also a decent amount of questions that I had no clue about despite studying well, and that for me were luck-based.
Hence there were many scores in the 60-70 range out of 95. Every point matters.

=> B+ (my final ranking was between 25-35 out of 70 students with 70+ bells)
reviews.comment_workload:
I put C for workload because it very much depends on you:
- Do you want to get as many bonuses (bells & whistles) as possible? Then very high workload! In my experience, each bell is about 1-2h of work. Some students got over 100+ bells, make the calculation!
- Do you not care about bonuses? Then the workload is OK. The core project parts are fairly easy and there are many resources online.

There are 4 projects though. They are all in C++. This means you will spend a lot of time during your semester writing code, debugging, testing... The project can be done in groups of 2 or individually. I would highly recommend having a partner (a good one preferably) as that will cut your workload in half.

There are also 3 homeworks.

For the final, you need to know lots of details as that is what is tested.

reviews.author: Yifan
reviews.title: Lots of practical experience, good foundation.
reviews.comment_content:
I really enjoyed the content. It is hands on and practical. You will end up with a solid ray tracer with animation capability that can handle transparency and refraction, etc.

Very proud of the final result even though I didn't do much bells and whistles. The content and the frameworks are old, like really old. But the knowledge about matrix and rendering processes are likely still pretty relevant, so I think it is still a good introductory course. Hopefully it will be updated eventually because it is indeed super old.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think the teaching is just fine. Reading from the slides as usual. The slides are pretty clear most of the time so I consider the teaching being fine.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading is clear and fine. If you want to get A range grade, I think it is basically required to full mark assignments (base score). From my understanding the bells and whistles cannot raise the base score, but allows higher ranking amongst students with same / similar base scores. So prioritize full base mark before considering bells and whistles.

Exams are exams, higher the better.

I got full mark for projects but pretty bad finals grade => B-
reviews.comment_workload:
I think the workload really depends on your interest, and if you can find some source code. If you don't want to do any bells and whistles (like me), one full Saturday is enough to finish one project. The 3rd and 4th ones are more difficult and thus might take longer, I would say maybe 10 hours of coding & debugging.

Many coding challenges like implementing gluLookAt and ray tracing, is possible to be found online (though not easy to find, B+ if you can find them, C- if you can't), implementing the matrix / systems on your own might be quite challenging, but definitely doable if you have a good understanding of the course material.

There was a lot of deadline extension given so even if you are a deadline fighter like me, things will be fine. (no bells and whistles though, sad)

reviews.author: zzzz24
reviews.comment_content:
basic image processing
ray tracing
parametric curves, surfaces...
reviews.comment_teaching: Terrible. Really do not understand what CK is talking about unless you replay the recording time and time again. I basically learnt from MIT online courses on youtube and slides from UT Austin.
reviews.comment_grading:
Harsh. Competition is fierce.

Final is actually very easy. Just some concepts. No calculation. And the majority of people have a good score. I learnt everything in 5 days and got 70+.

So the project is in fact the key to a good grade. Projects account for 60%. They can really make a difference. Treat them carefully and there are open source codes online for your reference (In fact, you can directly copy them. I am pretty sure someone does it.).

BW basically is of no use for normal students. You may need 40 BW to get just one subgrade up. Over a half of students get over 20 BW.

Again, students who take 4411 are all competitive and people are getting similar total scores. So to get a good grade, you must be very very very good at both projects and exam.
Someone has to be given a B- based on curves. I hope that is not you.

reviews.author: Argen
reviews.title: Good Course, Poor Teaching
reviews.comment_content:
Rich and detailed.

Most of necessary technique and maths are covered, including:
Image processing, display and color, 2D/3D Transformation, Hierarchical Modelling, Hidden Surface Algorithm, Ray Tracing, Ray Intersection, Shading, Texture Mapping, Parametric Curves, Particle System, Surface, Animation

You will learn a lot of concept, proof, and calculation in this course. In the meantime, the assignments push you to practice and implement them by coding.  Really a meaningful course in terms of content if you wish to learn more about CG.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Pretty poor as stated in title.

CK Tang tries to be a good instructor by making many jokes and mentioning interesting things. However, due to his ‘lagging’ way of speaking and rapid content switch, he is unable to express a fluent flow of lecture content. Students often feel confused with where he is explaining and how that is related to the topics before.
In most instances, we figure out what is happening by our actual implementation in assignment and revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
A normal distribution, can be further raised by bonus.

48% Projects
49% Final Exam
3% Paper Homework

Frankly speaking, if you expect an easy exam with light workload like those good-grade CC, you are strongly discouraged to enroll this course.

The exam is hard, there are many bonus task (aka Bells & Whistles, B/W) in projects which makes them tedious.
On the other hand, if you really make effort on the assignments to gain the bonus (basically impossible to finish all bonus since some of them are too difficult and troublesome), you earn a rise in subgrade.

My subjective view on B/W:
I need to spend around 1-2 hrs per Bell if I do it 100% on my own.
In my semester (relatively higher standard since students get at most 90B/W in the past):
~140 B/W (All completed): 3 subgrades up
~80 B/W: 2 subgrades up
~40 B/W: 1 subgrade up
reviews.comment_workload:
Depends. Can be an A or an E.

A: If you do neither wish to do bonus nor the 3% paper homework.
E: If you do as many B/W as you can, finish all paper homework, study all past papers.

reviews.author: luke_lu
reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course is interesting.
1. Image processing
2. Modeling
3. ray tracing
4. Curve and animation
This is a good introduction course if you want to know something about how computer graphic works.
reviews.comment_teaching: I would say CK's teaching is good. But would be kind of hard to follow if you are not used to his tone and pace of speaking.
reviews.comment_grading:
Projects:60%
Homeworks:3%(on completion)
Final Exam:37%

It's hard to judge the grade of this course. As CK said, It's very easy to pass this course, but hard to get A. Working on BWs(extra function of the project) may or may not help your grade.

If not considering BW, the grade is normal.
reviews.comment_workload:
Depends.
If you aim to pass this course, the workload is normal. But if you try to raise your grade by doing extra BW, the workload could go huge. There are a few people with 100+ BW. But I found getting 40+ is already time-consuming to my limit.

reviews.author: Dipsy
reviews.title: If you love programming, take this
reviews.comment_content:
Lots of things

1. color and display
2. Transformation
3. Ray tracing and illumination
4. Particle system
5. Animation (aka curves)
reviews.comment_teaching: If you used to his style of speaking, he is teaching fine. And there are a lot of fun in lectures and also many hints on exam so remember to attend lectures
reviews.comment_grading:
project and final around half half, and 3% written assignment

You have the option to do more bonus in order to boost your grade. It is known that this sem all students who have 3 digits of bells got A+. Even I am not very good still able to get A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The basic requirements for the projects are super easy, can be finished in a few hours

As for bonuses, there are also a lot of sources on GitHub, although some sources are actually made by my team. And remember to find a good teammate like what I did. Btw make sure you know how the code works as you are required to explain some code during the lab.

The assignments are graded by whether have you submitted, so just do a few questions and just submit it can still get full credits

I am really happy about doing all the bells and whistles so if you love coding you will have a happy time like me
